member.name: T:Microsoft.Graphics.Canvas.CanvasPathBuilder
member.summary: A path builder is used for creating freeform objects.
member.remarks: Paths consist of zero or more figures, where a figure is made up of straight or curved segments. Figures can be opened or closed.

example.p: The following is an example of how to create a simple CanvasGeometry using a CanvasPathBuilder object.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Graphics.Canvas.CanvasArcSize
member.summary: Specifies whether an arc should take the longer, or shorter way, around the ellipse to join its start and end points.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Graphics.Canvas.CanvasArcSize.Small
member.summary: Denotes that the angle of an arc's sweep should be π or less.
member.remarks: This causes arcs to take the "short" way around an ellipse, to join its start and end points.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Graphics.Canvas.CanvasArcSize.Large
member.summary: Denotes that the angle of an arc's sweep should be π or greater.
member.remarks: This causes arcs to take the "long" way around an ellipse, to join its start and end points.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Graphics.Canvas.CanvasFigureFill
member.summary: Specifies whether the interior of the figure is considered filled, for the purpose of drawing and geometry operations.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Graphics.Canvas.CanvasFigureFill.Default
member.summary: Specifies that the figure's interior may be filled using , and its interior is used by geometry operations that operate on fill.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Graphics.Canvas.CanvasFigureFill.DoesNotAffectFills
member.summary: Specifies that the figure will not affect calls, and its fill will not affect any geometry operations. Of course, the figure may still cause visible drawing with .

member.name: T:Microsoft.Graphics.Canvas.CanvasFigureLoop
member.summary: Specifies whether the figure is open or closed. This affects the appearance of fills and strokes, as well as geometry operations.

remarks.p: A closed figure, when drawn with a thick line, can appear differently from an open figure that is simply built to start and end with the same point. The closed figure will have a smooth, continuous line join where the figure starts and ends.
An open figure may also have start and end caps visible at the start and end, while a closed figure will not.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Graphics.Canvas.CanvasFigureLoop.Open
member.summary: Specifies that the figure may not necessarily begin and end with the same point.
member.remarks: Only open figures have start or end caps when drawn.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Graphics.Canvas.CanvasFigureLoop.Closed
member.summary: Specifies that the figure will be automatically closed, by connecting its end point back to its start point.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Graphics.Canvas.CanvasFigureSegmentOptions

member.name: F:Microsoft.Graphics.Canvas.CanvasFigureSegmentOptions.None

member.name: F:Microsoft.Graphics.Canvas.CanvasFigureSegmentOptions.ForceUnstroked

member.name: F:Microsoft.Graphics.Canvas.CanvasFigureSegmentOptions.ForceRoundLineJoin

member.name: T:Microsoft.Graphics.Canvas.CanvasFilledRegionDetermination
member.summary: Specifies how to determine which parts of a path are considered filled or unfilled.
member.remarks: The effects of this option are observable on self-intersecting geometry. See D2D1_FILL_MODE for more information.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Graphics.Canvas.CanvasFilledRegionDetermination.Alternate
member.summary: Specifies that self-intersecting regions are considered 'filled' based on the Alternate fill rule.

remarks.p: To determine whether a point is considered filled by the path, draw a ray from that point to some point obviously outside the path. Then examine the places where a segment of the path crosses the ray.
Count how many segments that the ray crosses. If it's an odd number, the point is considered filled by the path. If it's an even number, it's considered not to be.
Of course, this process is painstaking to evaluate by hand. Drawing and geometry operations evaluate the fill mode quickly.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Graphics.Canvas.CanvasFilledRegionDetermination.Winding
member.summary: Specifies that self-intersecting regions are considered 'filled' based on the Winding fill rule.

remarks.p: To determine whether a point is considered filled by the path, draw a ray from that point to some point obviously outside the path. Then examine the places where a segment of the path crosses the ray.

Keep track of a number, starting at zero. Add one for every clockwise intersection. Subtract one for every counterclockwise intersection. If the result is nonzero, the point is considered inside the fill area. A zero count means that the point lies outside the fill or clip area.
Of course, this process is painstaking to evaluate by hand. Drawing and geometry operations evaluate the fill mode quickly.

remarks.p: This method will fail if BeginFigure was called without a subsequent call to EndFigure.
